text: A vast, rust-colored plain beneath a pink sky. A smudge o mountains on the horizon. We hold on the hypnotic beauty the emptiness. It could almost be a photograph. ...a faint dust devil in the distance - swirling into for and disappearing within seconds. The camera EASES BACK. The move is barely detectable unti something breaks the bottom of the frame - a gnarled tang of metal, half-buried, covered with over half a century’s dust. Cyrillic script. A Soviet flag. It’s the Russian Mars 2 Lander, which failed to deploy it parachute and slammed into the ground 50 years ago - the first man-made object to touch Mars’ surface. Then, breaking the top of the frame, a hundred miles away from us, a bright flare in the sky descends obliquely. As breaks the frame - a RESOUNDING CHORD - uplifting and dangerous - a sternum-rattling chain of notes, as though music is willing this object into being. The flare fades until all that is left is a small, dark speck. It continues to descend rapidly until - coinciding with another chord - a supersonic parachute deploys. We CUT TO MUCH CLOSER as, a few hundred feet above the surface, a cocoon of balloons inflates and envelops the speck. The parachute disconnects and wafts away. The ballooned object begins a free fall. It hits the gro bouncing high up again and into a succession of smaller parabolas, until it finally comes to a rest. The balloons deflate. Within is a landing pod, a conical vessel with a rounded bottom scorched by the entry. Mechanical arms extend outwards from the sides to right t pod, so the cone is facing up. The cone splits into three separate plates which rotate outward and down, like the petals of a blossoming flower. REVEALING a ROVER - a six-wheeled chassis mounted with robotic hardware. It has two logos: NASA and VISTA. With a deep, guttural note from the sax, the rover’s “eye a 360 degree camera at the end of an extended rod - rises from the hardware to survey the landing zone. The eye til up, as if awakening. We CUT TO the Eye’s view - the distant horizon. The song reaches its crescendo. Then abruptly stops, taking us to:

The rover view of the horizon on a massive screen above 1 rows of room-wide desks covered with monitors, TECHNICIAN SCIENTISTS, and ENGINEERS behind each. Adjacent to the rover view is a digital map of Mars focus on the Hellas Basin with a marker for the rover’s locatio (and other surface robots and hardware), as well as a sec graphic showing Mars in its entirety and the position of multiple objects orbiting it. In the upper right-hand corner are two timecodes marking Earth and Mars times to the hundredth of a second:

Here on Earth, it is JUNE 16th, 2025, three and a half ye out from the scheduled crew launch to Mars. We CUT TO Flight Director ALVIN BARRIS (early 50s), and MARTHA HIRSCH (mid 40s), the Mission Control Director. Bo wear headsets. Low-key and workaday in manner.
Proceed to landing zone.
Go transmission.
Command sent. E.T.A for transmission 9 minutes, 2 seconds. E.T.A. to target: 2 hours, 12 minutes.

Copy. HAB 1 landing countdown remains on schedule for T-minus 33 hours, 35 minutes. We CUT TO the rear of the room where we find LAZ INGRAM ( British), the founder and CEO of VISTA, the private space exploration company teamed with NASA on the venture. He’s staring at the massive screen, arms folded. Laz has the bearing of a man in cool command. He’s a visionary who, like all visionaries, suffers from impatie but does not suffer fools. INT. VISTA HQ - PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 4 PRETESH KHATTAK (40s, Pakistani-American, the Chief Engin is with his team of engineers, including: MIN ZHOU (Asian American, 30s), VIVEK (Indian-American, 30s), GREG (beefy white, 20s), and WEI (Asian-American, 20s). They're watching the rover feed on a large mounted screen listening to the audio from Mission Control.
Feed incoming. A moment later, we see the view pan 90 degrees to another part of the horizon. The assembled watch with awe.
Give me high res and I.R.
Commands on deck.
Okay everyone, back to work. We've got data dumps coming in.

We follow a line of tire tracks in the fine dust, until w arrive at the ROVER. We come around front and see the tra extending to the landing module in the distance. The rover’s eye tilts down toward the soil. A mechanical swings out with a small drill at the end. The arm lowers the drill to the surface, whereupon the bi begins to spin, then descends into the soil. Its whirring the screech of pulverized rock the only sounds from here the horizon. We hear another mechanical sound: THE ROAR OF A CHAINSAW.

location: 40 MILES NORTH OF THE ARCTIC CIRCLE

text: TIGHT on a CHAINSAW biting into ice. CUT TO a WIDE SHOT to see a parka-clad MAN with the saw a the center of a large, frozen lake. There’s a snowmobile him and a HUSKY darting around nearby. CLOSER on the man, as he pushes the cut ice through, and water from the lake bubbles up through the hole. The man is TOM HAGERTY. He’s 52 but more fit than men 20 years his junior. A peppered beard dominates his face. There’s a matter-of-factness about him, a sureness and efficiency to his every movement. He fixes bait to a hook. Lowers the line into the hole wi rod. Props the rod up with a forked stick. Takes a moment look around at the desolate surface of the lake. It never gets old - the sublime. The husky starts to bark. Hagerty glances at the dog, who barking in the direction of another ice hole about thirty yards away. The pole is quivering on its stick. Hagerty makes his way over. Starts to reel in the line. T catch breaks the surface. A large rainbow trout. He unhoo the fish and heads back toward the snowmobile. TIGHT on Hagerty gutting the fish, the blood spilling on the white snow. He tosses some of the innards to the husk who hungrily devours them in a couple bites.
ROBERT CORDINE (50s) - the NASA LIAISON - is doing a stan interview with a news team.

The rover will confirm our soil composition estimates and give us a ground-up view of the landing. But tomorrow, that’s when interplanetary colonization really becomes tangible... We CUT TO the coverage filling the screen. The chyron rea Bob Cordine - NASA Mars Mission Director. CORDINE (CONT’D) By landing the HAB 1 module, we're putting the first technology on Mars that can support human life. The tests we do on HABs 1 and 2 - they’1l improve the subsequent HABs our crew will call home. HOLLY O'KEEFE (late 20s), Head of VISTA P.R. - to the
Got what you need?
We’re good. Thank you. As the Producer shakes hands with Cordine--
(to Cordine) Plane’s waiting. Cordine’s ASSISTANT escorts Cordine off.
(to Holly) When do I get Laz?  10
I gave you Cordine, didn’t I?
Cordine isn’t news. Laz is news.
ON Laz again, looking at the big screen.
Laz. Laz looks to Alvin, who is pointing to Laz’s ASSISTANT ov by the door. She’s tapping her wrist. Time to go.

LAUREN GUTIERREZ-HOLT (Latina, late 30s, VISTA’s Program Director), parka-clad, on her phone. She personifies competence and authority. It’s very windy. There’s a HELICOPTER in the background, CHOPPER PILOT beside it. Sh has to shout to be heard above the wind.
Tomorrow morning.
What was that? She covers the phone so it’s blocked from the wind.
Tomorrow morning. Earliest.
Laz in the back talking to the speaker phone. He’s stuck bumper-to-bumper traffic on the highway. There is no one the driver's seat. The car is driving itself.
Maggie’s adamant.  11
There’s nothing I can do about the weather.
Does tomorrow give you enough time to get back?
Depends how long it takes me to convince him.
Say again. Gusts of wind are tearing across the tarmac.
I’11 call you when I have the yes. She ends the call. Approaches the CHOPPER PILOT who was waiting for her to get off the phone. LAUREN (CONT’D) You sure we can’t try to beat the blizzard?
Hundred percent.
(pointing up) The sky’s crystal clear.
That doesn’t mean shit in Alaska.

location: 40 MILES NORTH OF THE ARCTIC CIRCLE

text: Hagerty and picking up. the Husky are minding the ice holes. The wind is Hagerty looks toward the sky, now beginning to fill with an oncoming front of clouds. Decides it’s bette not to remain out here, exposed. TIME CUT to fish to the husky jumps edge of the Hagerty packing up the poles and strapping the back of the snowmobile. He starts the engine. The onto the back sled. Hagerty drives toward the lake. The wind intensifies, snow beginning to slant down from the sky.
Cordine is already on the plane. Laz climbs aboard.
Bob.
We could’ve come in the same car.
We could've. As Laz settles into a seat not facing Cordine and uncaps waiting bottle of water--
I want to talk about Hagerty. Laz ignores him. As he retrieves a sleeping pill and wash it down with the water, the JET PILOT boards--
Gonna be a little bumpy on the way out. Fire in the mountains is throwing up some thermals. The two men nod and the pilot heads into the cockpit.
Near where you live, right?
Wind’s blowing the other way. Laz leans back and closes his eyes. A beat.
I think we should reconsider. Laz keeps his eyes closed.
Lauren’s already en route.
I just think - from NASA's perspective - Hagerty’s a wild card and we should--  13 Laz opens his eyes and drills Cordine with them.

We had this discussion. Then we had it again. We can go for number three, but I just took an Ambien, and I’m even more stubborn when I’m sleepy. Shall we continue? Cordine says nothing. Laz closes his eyes again.
Pretesh, Min, and Greg are standing in front of the half- built HAB 3 wearing smocks, surgical masks, latex gloves, plastic hair caps. Min shows them a small, rubber washer encircling a valve.
We ran the raw data again and our shake-bake analysis is off. We favored the wrong results.
The entry heat could be greater than its combustion limit.
It’s at least six centimeters under the shield.
We're worried about free air. Greg pokes his pinky finger into the tube.
Trapped here. Pressure might push it through the lock. She points to a coil of nylon rope in a compartment about foot away from the valve.
Could get this far. (turns back to him) Which is exactly what I said when I got outvoted by the other departments.  10.
Lauren is on her phone, looking out the window at the blizzard. On the other end we hear--
About 46 over because of OT this week.
How can we make it up?
A glass-walled conference room at the far end of the offi bull-pen. About a dozen DEPARTMENT HEADS gathered.
I’m working with Sam on materials.
Avisma will sell us titanium for 10 percent less. It’s a Russian company, so NASA might not--
You tested the samples?
Pretesh says they’re good.
Alright, I’1l talk to Bob. (shifting focus) Press?

We've got the big four, plus CNN, Bloomberg, and MSNBC. They all want one-on-- A knock on the glass. Everyone looks over to see Pretesh. mouths “Lauren?” Sam points to the speaker phone and mout “On now.” Pretesh opens the door.
Holly?  11.
Hi Lauren - it’s Tesh. (to the others) I need the room. TIME CUT to Lauren sitting on the edge of the bed. She lo stressed, but not shaken. She glances at her watch.
He’s in the hearing...
I’m not saying we have to stop the countdown... CUT BACK to the Conference Room. Pretesh is alone. PRETESH (CONT’D) At least not yet. We should have a better sense in a couple of hours.
Keep the circle tight. I don’t want this distracting him...

A closed hearing. Laz and Cordine are seated before the Appropriations Committee. Seated with them is Senator MARGARET SAYERS (early 60s, a Republican from Texas). She Ann Richards, if Richards was a conservative. They’re joi by the NASA ADMINISTRATOR - Cordine’s boss - DEIDRE KENT (early 50s, politically savvy with the polish of a career bureaucrat). The Chairman of Committee is TED WINTHROP (mid 40s, a Republican from Wyoming). Among others are Rep. HAL SCHNE (early 70s, Democrat from Massachusetts) and GAIL OGELBY (late 30s, Republican from Mississippi).
We're getting into double digits.
Billions that aren’t going to schools, to infrastructure...  12.
Mr. Chairman. Congress has already committed to this plan.
We approved 70 billion. Not 80. That’s 15 percent over-budget.

No, it’s right on budget. We told you 85 when we first proposed. You said make it 70 or we get nothing. Sayers discreetly touches Laz’s arm, a signal that says h should soften his tone. But Laz continues--
We all knew we’d have to come back for more. Our plan is still less than half of what my colleagues at NASA were proposing. Deidre shoots a look at Cordine while--
Our job’s to make sure we’re spending the taxpayers’ money responsibly. Your job is to justify that you are.
Mr. Chairman - if we can get back to the specific line items, I believe we can make clear how--
What is this 92 million for nanotech?
The FDA approved CRISPR testing on humans, and we need to fund it.
But is it mission critical?
We can’t fully predict the bio- stressers. Nanotech in the bloodstream gives us the ability to monitor and treat in real-time.  17 13.
By messing with genetic code.
I'd say improving.
Playing God.
I don’t believe in God, so I’m not in the business of playing him. Sayers, Cordine, and Kent stiffen. Ogelby is not pleased the response.

We all know God is a she, Laz. A few chuckles. This eases the tension in the room. SAYERS (CONT’D) The best way to see how the money is being spent is with your own eyes. She looks over to Laz with a look that says “step up”.
We hope you’1ll join us for the HAB landing tomorrow.
You can meet our top candidate for crew commander. Laz clenches his jaw. Sayers just made a promise he can’t necessarily deliver. We hear the whir of a snowmobile engine and CUT TO--

The snowmobile is struggling to make headway through the quickly deepening snow. It’s beginning to get dark, and w the storm, visibility is poor. It lurches to a halt. Hagerty tries to restart the engine but it stubbornly coughs, refusing to cooperate.  18 19 14. TIME CUT to Hagerty inspecting the engine. The husky hudd close to the snowmobile to get out of the gusts. Hagerty finds a snapped belt. Pulls it out. Checks his spare part bin, but there’s no backup belt to be found. He unpacks a tent and a shovel from the sled. Starts to d out a spot to camp.
Laz alone at a secluded table. He’s on his phone.
Should I cancel the trip?
Blizzard raging outside. Lauren’s in a booth at a greasy spoon world’s away from the plush restaurant Laz is in.
Tesh says they might need a delay.
For how long?
He doesn’t know. They have to work out a fix first.
Maybe it’s better if we put the breaks on everything. Takes the rush off you, gives me wiggle room with the clowns out here.
It didn’t go well?
It could've gone better.
What happened?  20 15. He sees a HOSTESS ushering Senator Sayers toward him.
She's walking toward me.
Game face, Laz. He ends the call. Stands up as Sayers approaches.
(to the Hostess) Vodka gimlet up. The Hostess nods and departs. As Laz and Sayers sit-- SAYERS (CONT’D) Well - I appreciate your honesty, if not your style.

A WAITRESS is setting down a piece of pie with a fresh sp while Lauren's phone is connecting a video call. We see a five-year old girl - Ellie - on the screen. Ther something slightly off about Ellie’s look and the fatigue her voice, but with the image tight on her face and the shakiness of the camera, we’re not sure...
Hey sweetheart.
Hi Mommy.
You going to bed soon?
Yeah. Are you?
I’m having some pie first. Lauren shows her the slice of pie with the phone.
I want some.
You already had dessert.
But now I want pie.
Daddy's right, it’s time for sleep. Give me a kiss. 16. Ellie blows her a kiss. Lauren blows one back. Her husban DELL (early 40s) comes onto the screen.
How’s it looking? She holds the phone to the window to show the blizzard. DELL (CONT’D) Don’t push him to go earlier than he’s comfortable with.
I won't.
You will.
I won't.
Can I see?
Show her the snow. Lauren holds the phone up to the window again. When she l back at the phone, Ellie has reappeared.
Did you see Santa Claus yet?
Santa Claus?  21 17.
Daddy says you’re at the North Pole.
Close to it.
So you'll see him.
Santa Claus doesn’t exist, darling. Ellie's face contorts. Dell appears back on the screen.
What are you doing?
We talked about this.
She’s five.
I’m not going to lie to her.
We'll call you tomorrow.
Dell...

She's crying now. I gotta go. The call ends. Lauren looks at herself in the spoon - an upside down, distorted image of herself. Allows herself t seconds of guilt, then buries it. Sets down the spoon. Picks up her phone. Starts to type something out. During which we hear HOWLING WIND, which t us to-- INT. ALASKA WOODS - HAGERTY’S TENT - NIGHT 21 Hagerty has a SATPHONE linked up to a TABLET DEVICE withi the cramped quarters, his dog taking up half the space intended for a single human.  22 18. On the screen, we see that he’s checking the weather forecast. There’s a large front making its way over north Alaska. He tries to zoom in on it but the website is not responding. He reorients the antenna on the satphone and holds it up toward the top of the flapping tent to get a better signa It works. Zooms in on his location. It looks pretty bad weather-wise. He clicks to a new window. His email. Many of the message are Google alerts for the VISTA/NASA Mars Mission. But am them, he sees an email from Lauren Gutierrez-Holt. The subject is: SEE YOU SOON Opens it. It reads: Since you won’t answer my emails, I’m showing up on your doorstep. Stuck in Fairbanks, but coming your way. Don’t shoot at the chopper. LGH ON Hagerty, brow furrowed in the blue glow of the screen.
This level of funding doesn’t happen without oversight.
You can’t outsource and micromanage at the same time. We promised faster and cheaper, and you promised autonomy.
Within reason.
Congress is slowing us down.
You won’t speed anything up by pissing in NASA’s eye at hearings.
Their skin in the game is covering their asses. Mine is getting to Mars.
Same as my skin.
Yours is the construction jobs in Houston.
If all I wanted was pork, there’s a helluva lot of easier ways to kill a pig.
I can’t get us there when we’re 15 billion short. I’m spending way too much time and effort--
Deal with it. There’s no Michelangelo without the Medicis.
The Medicis were smart enough to buy the paint and get the fuck out Michelangelo's way. She starts to cut her last piece of steak in half.
I would never tell you how to build a rocket. My expertise is Washington. I’1l get you the money. But that means rolling out the red carpet tomorrow.
The landing could be delayed. Off her look--
It’s a technical problem. There's a valve washer that--
Then you better get me Hagerty.  23 24 20.

Hagerty emerges from the tent with the husky. The snow is deep but falling lightly now. The wind has died down. TIME CUT to him crouched over a propane stove. He holds b ends of the snapped belt over the flame, melting the rubb then presses them together, fusing them. Holds the fused portion over the flame once again, pressing the bond toge with his gloved hands. Then pushes the belt into the snow solidify the bond. TIME CUT to Hagerty fitting the belt back into the engine The sky is clear now. He hears rotor blades. Looks up thr the tree branches and sees a helicopter dart by overhead. TIME CUT to Hagerty on the snowmobile, priming the fuel p then starting the ignition. The machine sputters to life. hops off and inspects the engine. The belt is working. Cl the cover lid and remounts the snowmobile. It lurches for through the deep snow. EXT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - DAY 24 A couple hours later. As Hagerty emerges from the woods i a clearing, we see a small cabin ahead - a modest abode t looks like a collision of the 19th and 21st centuries. Th structure itself could be out of a Jack London novel. But roof is covered with solar arrays and a large satellite d and antennas. Nearby are half a dozen 30-foot-tall, moder looking wind turbines. A few dozen yards from the cabin is the helicopter we saw earlier. Lauren is standing beside it in a big parka. She walks toward Hagerty as the snowmobile comes to a stop.
Thought you might've bailed.
Got caught in the blizzard. He retrieves the frozen trout from the snowmobile -- HAGERTY (CONT’D) Hungry?

I could eat.  25 21. INT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - MAIN ROOM - DAY 25 TIGHT on the filleted trout frying in a pan. We pull back see Hagerty at the stove, Lauren at small table. The two-room cabin is tidy. Essentials only. But in one corner is a computer station with several monitors. Top o the line equipment.
I emailed so many times, I grew calluses.
I read all of them.
Why didn’t you answer?
Didn't know if you were serious or just testing the waters.
Well I hope me flying to your doorstep shows how serious we are. Hagerty plates the fish and brings it to Lauren.
What about Cordine?
Approved.
He must've put up a fight.
Laz always wins the important ones. That’s why I work for him.
So how does this work?
In person. You fly back with me.
I’m not a wine and dine guy.  26 22.
The head of the Appropriations Committee is coming in.
You need to show me off.
It’s a few handshakes.
Before I’ve said yes.
I’m an optimist.
You know what my demand will be.
Laz is prepared to address that.
Will I get a yes or a or no?
You have to talk to him yourself. I won’t speak on his behalf. Hagerty cocks his head with deliberation. Then--

You eat. I’11l pack. On Lauren - relief. Hagerty disappears into the bedroom. INT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - BEDROOM - DAY 26 A fork scrapes across the plate in the other room as Hage packs a duffel with clothing. He takes a couple shirts do from hangers on a pole which stretches above the single b Among the shirts is a NASA flight jacket. He looks at the insignia for a moment. Resumes packing.  27 28 29 30 31 32 23. EXT. HAGERTY’S CABIN - DAY 27 The helicopter rotors swirl to life, kicking up billows o snow beneath. It lifts off the ground.
Hagerty and Lauren in the back, the husky crammed in too. Hagerty looks out the window, as the pristine Alaskan landscape stretches beneath them.

In stark contrast to the snowy peaks - the arid Santa Mon mountains. Smoke is billowing upwards from a ridge- line. the distance, we see a private plane making a wide turn t position itself for final approach.
The camera is beneath the fuselage of the plane. We see t plane’s shadow appear over the runway, get closer, then h the squelch of the tires, as they contact the ground with puffs of burnt rubber.

An Electric Minivan pulls through a security gate at the entrance of a massive building that stretches for a quart of a mile. The VISTA logo in three-story letters along th side. The van parks in a space next to the entrance. Laz, Sayers, Cordine, and Winthrop get out. Laz’s ASSISTANT is waiting. Holds open the door as they enter.

They approach a set of double doors. Above them is a sign which reads: BUILD FACILITY. Laz holds his phone up to a scanner. The doors unlock with a click. As Laz opens the door, we hear the hum of machines, a beeping forklift, me against metal, a symphony of construction.  33 34 24.

EXTREME WIDE SHOT from above, as the foursome make their down a central corridor. The room is vast. One area is dedicated to satellites. Another to the HAB 3 build. A prototype section for the Lander/Mars-Ascent Vehicle (LMA An air-lock portion with engineers in sterilized jumpsuit and hoods doing post-assembly cleaning and stress testing laser cutting and welding section. And at the far end of the room - dominating an entire sid the assembly of a massive rocket. INT. PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 34 Pretesh and Min are showing Alvin a copy of the valve--
When we changed the washer from metal to rubber, we did three shake and bakes. Two were within the margin, one wasn’t.
How does a red flag like that--
You were pushing us on the launch.
(more diplomatic) Everyone was under pressure. I know you were too.
Give me odds.
8 to 1.2 percent catastrophic.
What’s the fix?
We can’t get inside with the arm, so our focus is entry angle.
My team’s crunching numbers.  35 25.
(to Pretesh) Freeze the countdown?
We could use more time.
Alright. I’1l freeze it. (as he exits) Get me within the margin.
Sayers and Winthrop are dwarfed by the massive rocket the are standing near, gazing at it. Laz and Cordine are a fe yards away talking to Alvin.
When do I get to meet Hagerty?
They're in the air now.
I want a picture with him. Next to one of these.
I’m sure we can make that happen. Laz and Cordine approach them as Alvin walks off.
Countdown’s frozen.
Why?
There’s a valve we're taking a look at. Our engineers are working on the problem.
We talking hours, or...
Hopefully. Might be days.  26
(to Sayers) I’ve got to be back for the leadership caucus Thursday morning.
We'll do our best.
(to Winthrop) These sort of things are common.
(to Laz) Seems serious.
Everything’s serious 80 million miles from earth.

I'd like to pray. Winthrop takes Sayers’ hand. He means an actual prayer. They're all a little taken aback by it. WINTHROP (CONT’D) Bob? Cordine takes Winthrop’s other hand, going with the flow. WINTHROP (CONT’D) (to Laz) I know you’re not a believer...but if you'll indulge me. Sayers shoots a look to Laz. Time to play nice. Laz takes Sayers’ and Cordine’s hands to complete the circle. Winth bows his head and closes his eyes. WINTHROP (CONT’D) Dear heavenly father... Sayers and Cordine follow suit, bowing their heads and closing their eyes. Laz keeps his open. We start to hear deep drone from the baritone sax...  36 37 38 39 27. WINTHROP (CONT’D) Please give your guidance and blessing to the engineers... INT. VISTA HQ - PRETESH’S OFFICE - DAY 36 Pretesh, Min, and a team of six other engineers in a heat discussion. Greg finishes an equation on a dry erase boar then Min crosses something out, pointing to an entry-angl diagram--
...that they might be enlightened with your infinite wisdom...
Alvin approaches Martha and says something. She speaks in the headset. We CUT TO to the big screen where we see the countdown clock FREEZE.
...that this delay be brief, and we proceed soon with the mission at hand...
Holly is briefing several news camera crews and a dozen reporters on the delay. One of the reporters asks how lon the delay we be. Holly says she doesn’t know.
...-So that with the world’s eyes on us, we can show what gifts you have endowed us with...
Hagerty’s POV out the window, a moonless sky filled with stars above a bank of clouds stretching to the horizon.
..-And continue on our path into the magnificent universe you have created...  40 41 42 43 28.
WIDE SHOT of the four linking hands from above. Tiny in relation to the booster rocket. The drone gets louder.
Amen.

A SAXOPHONE PLAYER is playing the baritone sax that we've heard throughout the episode thus far. Circular breathing Cheeks and veins straining, eyes closed, sweat on the bro He’s swaying back and forth slowly, as he wills the unbro drone into being.
As the drone continues, we see the ISS serenely orbiting earth, passing from day into night, the sun disappearing behind the earth.
The drone is replaced with a SWISHING sound. KAYLA FORD (early 40s, African-American) is floating in m gravity looking out the window. Her face lit up by the su blue reflection on earth.
Hank. HANK (mid 50s) is working at the other end of the compartment. He looks over.
You can see that fire in the Santa Monica mountains. He floats over. Looks out the window. Kayla points.
Right there.  44 45 46 29.
Yeah, I see it.

Big one, huh? We CUT TO their POV and see the west coast of North Ameri below, major metropolises, a web of bright lights, Los Angeles dominating. Just to the north of the city is a st of glowing fire lines, reddish orange in contrast to the yellow-white electric light. Fingers of smoke stretch for twenty miles to the east. As we slowly push in on the tan of fire lines and smoke, we hear the sound of a raging a fire.

Fifty foot flames. Trunks and branches snapping and crackling. The relentless violence of nature. EXT. LAZ’S MANSION - NIGHT 45 An electric minivan winds up the driveway of a sprawling Italian villa. We can see the orange glow of the forest f in the far distance behind the mountains.

DAVID, Laz's butler, shows Hagerty and Lauren into a larg living room. Everything is packed up in boxes. The walls floors are bare. Most of the furniture is pushed to one s of the room along with the boxes and rolled up rugs, exce for one sofa and two chairs placed in the center. A bubbl wrapped Warhol self-portrait is leaned up against one wal upside-down. Laz is sitting on the sofa. He doesn’t stand when Hagerty Lauren enter.
Forgive the appearance.
Moving out or moving in?
Out.  30.
Not the fire...
Divorce.
Been there.
(re the chairs) Please. Hagerty and Lauren sit in the chairs opposite the sofa.
Why Alaska?
Where my mother grew up.
Back to your roots.
Something like that.
